alerts.headline: squall warning in effect
alerts.description:
Squalls with wind gusts up to 40 knots are expected or occurring in the area.

A line of thunderstorms over Michigan is moving northeast at 50 knots and is expected to cross southern portions of Lake Huron.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
alerts.instruction: Mariners are advised to prepare for squalls. If underway, seek safe harbour immediately.

alerts.headline: severe thunderstorm watch in effect
alerts.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts.

Hazard:
Wind gusts up to 90 km/h.

Timing:
Ending this evening

Additional information:
A line of thunderstorms is tracking east over southwestern Ontario. This line of thunderstorms has been weakening, however, strong wind gusts continue to be a possibility through the evening.

###

Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.

Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.

For more information: https://www.ontario.ca/page/be-prepared-emergency.
alerts.instruction:
Lightning kills and injures Canadians every year. Remember, when thunder roars, go indoors!

Emergency Management Ontario recommends that you take cover immediately if threatening weather approaches.

alerts.headline: fog advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring over some areas.

Patchy dense fog will linger across parts of the region this evening.

###

Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance.

alerts.headline: special weather statement in effect
alerts.description:
Thunderstorms are expected this evening. 

What:
Isolated wind gusts up to 70 km/h.

When:
This evening.

Additional information:
A line of thunderstorms is tracking east over southwestern Ontario. This line of thunderstorms has been weakening, however, strong wind gusts continue to be a possibility through the evening. 

Small hail and locally heavy rain are also possible.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.

alerts.headline: squall warning ended
alerts.description:
Squalls have weakened or moved out of the area.


###

alerts.headline: squall warning in effect
alerts.description:
Squalls with wind gusts up to 40 knots and frequent lightning are expected or occurring in the area.

A line of thunderstorms over central portions Lake Erie is moving northeast at 35 knots.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
alerts.instruction: Mariners are advised to prepare for squalls. If underway, seek safe harbour immediately.

alerts.headline: severe thunderstorm watch ended
alerts.description:
Conditions are no longer favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms.


###

alerts.headline: freezing rain warning in effect
alerts.description:
Freezing rain ending near midnight.

What:
Patchy freezing rain lingering this evening.
Minimal additional ice accretion.
Slippery surfaces and broken tree branches from ice build-up.

When:
Ending near midnight.

Additional information:
A few locations, including Ottawa Airport, remain just below the freezing mark this evening. These areas are expected to climb above freezing in the next few hours, bringing an end to the freezing rain.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas. Slow down driving in slippery conditions. Watch for taillights ahead and maintain a safe following distance. Beware of branches or electrical wires that could break under the weight of ice.

alerts.headline: freezing rain warning in effect
alerts.description:
Freezing rain ending near midnight.

What:
Prolonged period of freezing rain.
Ice accretion of 5 to 15 mm.
Power outages.
Slippery surfaces and broken tree branches from ice build-up.

When:
Ending near midnight.

Additional information:
An extended period of freezing rain will continue this evening. Temperatures are forecast to rise above the freezing mark in the next few hours, bringing an end to the freezing rain.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Slow down driving in slippery conditions. Watch for taillights ahead and maintain a safe following distance. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. Beware of branches or electrical wires that could break under the weight of ice.

alerts.headline: squall warning ended
alerts.description:
Squalls have weakened or moved out of the area.


###

alerts.headline: squall warning ended
alerts.description:
Squalls have weakened or moved out of the area.


###

alerts.headline: special weather statement in effect
alerts.description:
Moderate winds resulting in continuing impacts from the ice storm.

What:
Isolated wind gusts near 50 km/h in thunderstorms tonight.
Northwest winds gusting to 40 km/h Monday morning and afternoon.
Additional damage to trees and utilities possible. 

When:
Thunderstorms late this evening into the overnight hours. 
Moderate northwest winds beginning late Monday morning into the afternoon. 

Additional information:
The ice storm left anywhere from 10 to 25 mm of ice on surfaces. Although temperatures have risen slightly above freezing, strong winds gusting to 40 or 50 km/h may result in further impacts.

A line of thunderstorms is tracking east over southern Ontario. This line of thunderstorms may bring wind gusts near 50 km/h. 

Monday morning moderate northwest winds gusting near 40 km/h associated with a cold front are expected to develop and continue into the afternoon.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.

affected_areas.area_description: Fenelon Falls - Balsam Lake Park - Northern Kawartha Lakes
Watford - Pinery Park - Eastern Lambton County
St. Thomas - Aylmer - Eastern Elgin County

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect.

What:
Snowfall totals of 5 to 15 cm.
Reduced visibility in snow. 

When:
Continuing this evening and ending overnight.

Additional information:
The region will be affected by the northwestern edge of a winter storm. Up to 15 cm of snowfall is possible in the Wawa area with lesser amounts expected farther west towards White River and Marathon.

Note that for areas to the south and east, winter storm warnings are in effect with significantly higher snowfall totals and the threat of freezing rain expected.

###

Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

alerts.headline: freezing rain warning in effect
alerts.description:
Hazardous ice storm this evening and overnight tonight.

What:
Freezing rain with significant ice accretion of 10 to 20 mm.
Icy and slippery conditions.
Utility outages and tree damage.

When:
Continuing this evening through early Monday morning.

Additional information:
A prolonged period of freezing rain is expected. For some areas, this has the potential to be a major ice storm.

Freezing rain may change over to rain this evening for locations near the North Channel and the city of North Bay as temperatures briefly rise above the freezing mark. Precipitation will transition to ice pellets and then snow from west to east Monday morning.

Easterly winds will become northerly on Monday morning with gusts up to 50 km/h. This may exacerbate the situation if there is ice build-up on tree limbs and power lines.

###

Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. Extended and widespread utility outages are possible.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Beware of branches or electrical wires that could break under the weight of ice.

affected_areas.area_description: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island

alerts.headline: freezing rain warning in effect
alerts.description:
Ice storm continues this evening and overnight tonight.

What:
Freezing rain with significant ice accretion of 10 to 20 mm.
Icy and slippery conditions.
Utility outages and tree damage possible.

When:
Continuing this evening through early Monday morning.

Additional information:
Freezing rain may change over to rain this evening for portions of Manitoulin Island where temperatures rise above the freezing mark. Precipitation will transition to ice pellets and then snow early Monday morning.

Easterly winds gusting up to 50 km/h could exacerbate the situation if there is ice build-up on tree limbs and power lines. Winds will become northerly early Monday morning.

###

Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. Extended and widespread utility outages are possible.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Beware of branches or electrical wires that could break under the weight of ice.

###

alerts.headline: winter storm warning in effect
alerts.description:
Winter storm continues this morning. 

What:
Freezing rain with significant ice accretion of 5 to 15 mm.
Utility outages possible.
Slippery surfaces and broken tree branches from ice build-up.
Snowfall and ice pellet amounts up to 20 cm north of a line from Ranger Lake to Cobalt.

When:
Ending late this morning.

Additional information:
Snow or ice pellets has transitioned to freezing rain in most communities. Freezing rain is expected to be most significant for locations south of a line from Ranger Lake to Cobalt where ice storm conditions are possible. Precipitation will transition back to ice pellets and then snow from west to east this morning.

Conditions will improve late this morning as the weather system exits the province.

###

Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions.

affected_areas.area_description: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay

alerts.headline: winter storm warning in effect
alerts.description:
Winter storm continues this morning.

What:
Snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm.
Peak snowfall rates of 2 to 5 cm per hour.
Risk of freezing rain.

When:
Ending late this morning.

Additional information:
Snow may mix with or transition to ice pellets at times through this morning, particularly for locations along and south of a line from Gogama to Kirkland Lake. A risk of freezing rain will also exist in these areas. For locations that receive ice pellets and freezing rain, snowfall amounts will be reduced. A sharp gradient in snowfall amounts may exist to the north and south of the axis of heaviest snow. All precipitation will transition to snow from west to east this morning.

Conditions will improve late this morning as the weather system exits the province.

###

Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.
